Mr. Swantek was the principal violist of the Air Force Strings, one of the several performing groups of The United States Air Force Band in Washington, D.C. During his 20 years with the Air Force, Mr. Swantek performed at the White House for Presidents Clinton, Ford, Reagan, Bush, and Carter, and at the Pentagon and State Department for many heads of state and other foreign dignitaries.

As a freelance musician in the Washington area, Mr. Swantek was the principal violist of the National Gallery Orchestra and the Post-Classical Ensemble. He was also a “first-call” substitute for the National Symphony Orchestra, which offered him the opportunity to travel and perform in Russia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania under the direction of renowned conductor and cellist Mstislav Rostropovich.

While at Boston University, Mr. Swantek had the good fortune of studying viola with Bernard Kadinoff, violist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He studied chamber music with Eugene Lehner, Endel Kalam, Raphael Hillyer, Rafael Druian, and the Muir String Quartet. At The Catholic University of America, Mr. Swantek studied with Richard Parnas, former principal violist in the National Symphony Orchestra, and with Rafael Druian. He received additional experience and training as a member of the Spoleto Festival Orchestra in Charleston, South Carolina, and at Tanglewood (then the Berkshire Music Center) as a Boston Symphony Fellow, working with many conductors such as Kurt Masur, Seiji Ozawa, Charles Dutoit, Joseph Silverstein, and Leonard Slatkin.

Currently, Mr. Swantek is a member of the Grand Rapids Symphony Orchestra viola section. He is also an Affiliate Professor of Music at Grand Valley State University, teaching viola and general education music courses.

Eric Tanner

Principal Second Violin

Principal Second Violin

Richard and Helen DeVos Chair

Eric Tanner began violin studies at the age of three and made his solo debut performing Saint-Saens’ Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso with Nathan Gottschalk and the Pioneer Valley Symphony in Greenfield, Massachusetts, at age 13. He studied at the Eastman School of Music and received bachelor’s and master’s degrees in music from the University of Massachusetts and the Manhattan School of Music, respectively.

Principal Second Violin of the Grand Rapids Symphony since 1999, Eric has made his solo appearance with the orchestra. His previous solo appearances include performing the Brahms Double Concerto along with his brother, cellist Mark Tanner, in 2005, and Vivaldi’s Four Seasons in 2007.

Eric has held positions in the Florida Philharmonic, New Orleans Symphony, Springfield Symphony and American Sinfonietta. While serving as Concertmaster of the North Miami Beach Symphony, he performed the Bruch Violin Concerto with the orchestra. Along with violinist Joshua Bell, Eric was a finalist in 1982 in the first annual SEVENTEEN Magazine and General Motors Concerto Competition, in addition to other competitions and awards.

Eric performs extensively as a chamber musician, both as second violinist with the Grand Rapids Symphony’s DeVos String Quartet and as first violinist of the Perugino String Quartet, which was founded at Grand Valley State University, where Eric also taught violin from 1997 to 2011. With the Perugino Quartet, Eric has performed in New York City’s Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts at the invitation of the Juilliard Quartet.

The many music festivals and concert series he has performed at include regular appearances with the Saugatuck, Sunflower, Buzzards Bay, Waterloo and Grand Teton music festivals, as well as performances in Germany and Austria.

Eric resides in East Grand Rapids with his wife, cellist Stacey Bosman Tanner, and their two daughters, Elizabeth and Charlotte.

Updated March 2020

Collette VandenBerg

Violin

Violin

Colette VandenBerg began playing piano at age 4 and violin at age 7. Her first teacher was “an awesome grad student” from the University of Michigan.

She graduated from Western Michigan University with a Bachelor's degree in Music Education and taught public school music for 22 years. She has been a member of the Grand Rapids Symphony since 1974, taking a few years off to teach out of state.

Today, Collette continues to teach private strings. She adores her students and feels very privileged to be their teacher, and she considers teaching to be as important in her life as being a professional violinist.

A cat lover who had a calico cat who lived to be almost 21 years old, Collette then adopted a wonderful black cat named Jacob. Two years after he passed away, she rescued a sweet senior cat named Baby Girl.

Collette’s hobbies include taking walks at Frederik Meijer Gardens & Sculpture Park and at Grand Haven; attending concerts at Meijer Gardens, at the Grand Rapids Art Museum, and at Worship on the Waterfront, also in Grand Haven.

Her other great joy is being an aunt and a great aunt to her wonderful nieces and nephews as well as to their children.

Updated April 2020

Robert Ward

Bass Trombone

Bass Trombone

Mr. Ward has been the Bass Trombonist of the Grand Rapids Symphony since 1980. A native of West Michigan, Bob attended Michigan State University earning a B.A. in 1980 and a M.M. in 1991, both in music education. His teachers include Curtis Olson, Edward Kleinhammer, Frank Crisafulli, Arnold Jacobs, and Edwin Anderson. In addition to his duties with the GRS, Bob also taught orchestra and band for 28 years at Grand Rapids Public Schools and Lowell Area Schools, and is an Emeritus member of the MSBOA. He is still active as a music educator, teaching lessons to Grand Rapids area trombone, euphonium, and tuba students.

Every August since the year 2000 Bob performs with the Cabrillo Festival Orchestra, an internationally renowned contemporary music festival based in Santa Cruz, California. He is also a founding member and arranger of the brass octet, Majestic Brass of Grand Rapids. Bob has performed with the Detroit, Lansing, and Kalamazoo Symphonies, and in 1988 he toured Korea, Taiwan, and Japan with the National Repertory Orchestra.

Bob is married and has four daughters. His hobbies include camping with his family, hiking and backpacking, kayaking, golf, and woodworking. In 2014 Bob thru-hiked the John Muir Trail, backpacking 250 miles from Mt. Whitney to Yosemite National Park in the High Sierra of California.

Olga Ziabrikova

Viola

Viola

A native of Moscow, Russia, Olga Ziabrikova joined the Grand Rapids Symphony in 2001.

She began her music studies at age 6 on violin and piano. Her father, Yuri, was a singer who cultivated the love of music and art in his children. After hearing one of her father’s musician friends play viola, she fell in love with the sound and switched to viola at the age of 14.

Olga got her first professional job as principal violist of the “Vivaldi-Orchestra” of Moscow at the age of 18 shortly after graduating from the Academic Music College at the Moscow Conservatory. She performed and traveled extensively with that orchestral group for five years, including two lengthy tours of the United States.

In 1996, Olga immigrated to the United States where she received a master’s degree in music performance from Western Michigan University.

Olga is married to the Charley Lea, principal trumpet of the Grand Rapids Symphony.
